ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked thinking about how to practically translate aesthetics and theory of resistance into the real world, and across multiple struggles. It's something I've been thinking about a lot and I do feel we got a good mix of how to approach each.

I learned a great deal about the history of various resistance movements, and improved my writing significantly. The greatest thing that I took from this class were the class discussions surrounding the challenges to organized resistance and the possibility for change.

I learned about the theoretical history of resistance in the West, recent resistance movements and their theoretical critiques, and a more structured framework in which to discuss resistance in practice (aesthetics, tactics, strategies, etc.).
this course combined theories of resistance with case studies each week. it was more of an intellectual history course grounded in cases of real resistance
I learned about various histories and theories of resistance, and skills around analyzing the historical connections of contemporary politics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really loved this class and the readings! I think one way it could be improved might be to look at a few more third world applications, or even just colonial world applications.

This was a really amazing class. The readings could be enhanced by expanding the global and cultural breadth of the selections. The discussion was wonderful, but it could also be improved with less lecturing and more time for student contribution.

I really appreciated the TF, who would participate in discussion like one of the students. I think the professor did a wonderful job selecting a variety of readings from different perspectives, as well as always supplying us with each text's background information and historical context. I think everyone was comfortable participating in discussion and we represented a healthy range of experiences. I would have appreciated more guidance and detailed feedback on my short paper, so I knew what to aim for in the final project. I think the TF or the instructor could have met with each of the students individually sometime in the middle of the term for a checkup.
Terry is a great discussion leader! conversations flows well and he asks great questions to get us thinking about the materials

The course covers an exciting, engaging and rigorous selection of materials and topics. The classroom environment was a delight to be a part of. Each class opened with student presentations which were in-depth and fascinating.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think overall the student presentation and zoom seminar format worked well
The seminar format and additional reading presentations worked very well for this class.

I appreciated the instructors' efforts to provide organized digital texts of all the readings on Canvas--it made studying easier and more accessible. I think the seminar felt a bit long at times, especially because it was online. I would sometimes begin to experience eye-sore in the middle of class sometimes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! It's a bit of a challenge if you don't have a very strong background in philosophy, but I really enjoyed learning material that we SHOULD have difficulty grappling with.

If you are interested in connecting theory and practice, yes! It was very interesting to discuss Rosa Luxembourg and Black Lives Matter in the same course, with equal focus on theoretical illustrations of successful resistance movements, and to critique or apply them in the context of social movements.
yes! they syllabus is great and resistance is a very interesting lens to use to view history
Yes! Take this class if you want to talk about interesting and important topics in the history and theory of resistance with a great group of people and a wonderful professor.

As long as you genuinely commit to doing all the reading (and mayhaps already have some thoughts about resistance), yes! The assigned readings, as a wide-ranging introduction to a number of theories and traditions of resistance, were generally well-selected and always engaging, and the structure of the course gave us a number of opportunities to explore our own interests. Above all, Professor Renaud was fantastic. I only wish I'd taken a class with him sooner! He's great at facilitating discussion and really cares for his students. And if you get to take this course, don't pass up the opportunity to go to office hours and engage in some (at risk of sounding incredibly pretentious) intellectually stimulating conversation.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/a
Weekly seminars and readings; assignments include 1 presentation, 1 short paper, 1 discussion report, and 1 final project.
